data.text:
Full Name: Lester Bowles Pearson

Profession: Prime Minister of Canada

Biography: Lester B. Pearson served as Prime Minister of Canada and won the Nobel Peace Prize. He began his career as a diplomat and became known for his work in international relations.

Pearson grew up in Ontario as the son of a Methodist minister. He excelled in sports during his youth, playing rugby, ice hockey, and baseball. During World War I, Pearson served as a medical orderly and later as a pilot, earning the nickname "Mike."

After the war, Pearson joined the Department of External Affairs in 1928. He rose through the ranks of Canada's diplomatic service, playing key roles in founding the United Nations and NATO. In 1957, Pearson won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in resolving the Suez Crisis.

Pearson entered politics and became leader of the Liberal Party. He served as Prime Minister of Canada from 1963 to 1968, leading two minority governments. During his time as Prime Minister, Pearson introduced several significant policies.

His government established universal healthcare and the Canada Pension Plan. Pearson also introduced the Maple Leaf as Canada's national flag. In 1967, his administration implemented the world's first points-based immigration system.

Pearson faced challenges during his tenure, including tensions with French President Charles de Gaulle over Quebec independence. He also had a notable encounter with United States President Lyndon B. Johnson concerning Canada's stance on the Vietnam War.

In 1968, Pearson retired from politics, handing over leadership to Pierre Trudeau.

Born: April 23, 1897

Birthplace: Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Generation: Lost Generation

Star Sign: Taurus
